11:14 am
PM

Over the past eight years, global central banks have progressively eased policy, including through unconventional means. The Fed led the way, followed by the Bank of England, and then the Bank of Japan and the European Central Bank. In the initial years, worries centered on whether ultra-easy policy would eventually lead to ultra-high inflation. But in the past few years, there has been a remarkable turn-around. The concern now is that central banks will not be able to boost inflation and nominal growth, no matter what they do. After all, if the current level of unprecedented policy easing has not worked, what will?

Signs of skepticism – about central banks’ ability to generate inflation – abound. Medium-term inflation expectations in Japan are close to zero, and are near record lows in Europe and the US. The US fed funds curve is pricing in about two rate hikes by end-2017, well below the Fed’s median forecast. And the Bank of Japan’s recent negative rate move has been met by a sharp strengthening of the yen – the exact opposite of the hoped-for response.

Barclays’ Equity Gilt Study provides in-depth analysis of the most topical macro issues, with a medium to long-term horizon. Perhaps no other economic issue is now as important as central bankers’ battle to create inflation, and the new tools they are trying to achieve their goal. This is a common theme running through most of this year’s publication. Chapter 1 argues that much of the decline in individual countries’ domestic inflation has been the result of global factors, including global labor markets. Although policy makers have not yet lost control of inflation developments, easy monetary policies are likely to be around for a long time. Some of these will be radical, including using negative rates to challenge the zero lower bound.

PM

The US is the one major economy where the central bank has felt confident enough to start a hiking cycle. But even in the US, a structural shift has lowered trend growth and the natural rate of interest (r*), as we discuss in Chapter 2. Our framework suggests that US monetary policy is closer to neutral than commonly thought. We expect Fed hikes to proceed very slowly and over many years, in line with a slow rise in r*. For other developed economies struggling with disinflation, negative nominal interest rates are likely to persist. But, as we discuss in Chapter 3, this policy has its own frictions, including the long-term nominal commitments of pensions and insurers, an aversion to nominal losses, and currency as an alternative. But well-designed tiering of negative rates could work around some of these frictions and provide avenues for easing. Finally, in Chapter 4, we explore linkages between population dynamics and global imbalances. In our view, demographic developments imply that China and Europe will remain capital exporters over the next 10-15 years, while the US and UK should remain net capital importers.

The Equity Gilt Study has been published continually since 1956, providing data, analysis and commentary on long-term asset returns in the UK and the US. In addition to the macro discussions, this publication contains a uniquely deep and consistent database: the UK data go back to 1899 and the US data, provided by the Center for Research in Security Prices at the University of Chicago, begin in 1925. We hope that this year’s effort lives up to the publication’s rich history and provides you, our readers and clients, with useful inputs into your long-term investing decisions.

PM

11:17 am
PM

( http://discussions...eriously-long-view wink smile )

BE

By which I mean it's not outright negative.

BE

Basically, Aggreko was priced for a 2016 warning and that hasn't arrived. Hence the rally.

11:17 am
BE

Morgan Stanley incoming.

BE

FY 2015 results are fine, the outlook for Local rental is softer, while it is
positive on the prospect pipeline for utility (this has always been the
case) and has extended Japan for 2yrs and churn is expected to rise,
bad debts are up (and there is some cautious commentary around this)
and new contract wins so far are below 2015’s level.

BE

FY 15 numbers: Revenue (ex-fuel) of £1501m is 0.3/-1.5% vs MSe/Cons .
Trading profit of £271m is 2% below MSe and in line with consensus. PBT of
£252m compares to MSe £252m (it expected to be “towards the bottom of its
range of £250-270m and includes a £4m higher provision for bad debts). EPS
of 71.7p is -2/2% vs MSe/Cons.
Utility wins look light and churn is expected to rise: Utility contract wins
of 640MW compares to 561MW to 8th Nov and 697MW in 2014, implying
163MW in Q4 (219MW Q414) and 79MW since the Nov trading update
(60MW 2014). It has signed 140MW so far in Q1 vs 287MW at this stage in
2015 and extended its 150MW in Japan for 2yrs. It expects churn to be 30% in
2016e which compares to 8/24/22 Q1/2/3 in 2015.
In terms of the outlook, it’s a bit of a mixed bag with Local weaker and
a healthy prospect pipe for Utility (which has always been the case)
and more concern on bad debts: It's happy with consensus PBT of £233m
(MSe £216m, but it started that way last yr), trading is softer in Rental
Solutions (US especially and Q1 sounds weak), Power Solutions has “softer
trading conditions”, while it has a “strong order book” (up to 40k MW months,
+5%, but will reflect extending Japan for 2yrs, Bangladesh for 3yrs and
phasing is unsure), the prospect pipeline is “healthy” (it always has been, it's
been more about a weak conversion rate), it expects the churn rate to go back
up to 30% (implying it needs c 900MW to stand still) and it “continues to
monitor the geopolitical situation in Yemen, Libya and Venezuela (400MW of
fleet and £60/14m of rev/EBIT).
Capex up, but probably reflects some fleet diversification: Capex is
expected to be £250m for the FY, which compares to guidance of £120m for
1H as it ramps up the new gas fleet, but this is also fleet diversification and not
based upon new orders (as we understand).

11:18 am
BE

And Deutsche.

BE

Underlying PBT of £252m compared to Company consensus at £247m and guidance (reiterated in November) of £250-270m. EPS of 71.7p compared to Company consensus at 70p (Bloomberg at 72.1p). The proposed DPS for the FY comes in at 27.12p, flat on the prior year. Aggreko reported FY 15 revenues of £1.56m against Company consensus at £1.57bn. Underlying revenue growth was -3% with Q4 implied at c.-1% benefitting from the 53rd week (Q3 -7%, Q2 c.-8%, Q1 +4%). The Group trading margin was 17% (FY 14: 19%) and the ROCE at 16% (FY 14: 19%).
Outlook: The outlook for PBT is “slightly lower than the prior year on a constant currency basis, in line with current consensus.” Company consensus of £233m implies an 8% decrease year-on-year. We expect the company to say more about the contractual FX protection in Argentina. The statement talks about a reduction in H1 profits at a Group level. The outlook for PS Utilities business is encouraging but the outlook for PS Industrial and Rental Solutions is weaker. Aggreko say they are on target to deliver £80m of savings by 2017.

BE

Capex guidance
Capex came in at £254m in FY 15 in line with guidance for £250. H1 16E fleet capex guidance of c.£120m was introduced in November, and a FY 16E guidance of £250m has been announced today.
Power Solutions Utilities – higher debt provisions, better outlook
Organic growth was -11% implying Q4 at c.-8% (Q3 -21%, Q2 -22%, Q1 +7%). Contracts signed stood at 640MW up from 561MW as of Q3 (FY 14 757MW including 170MW peak shaving). The debtor provision was increased by $11m mainly due to Yemen and Venezuela. EBITA was down 28%, with the margin down five percentage points. Japan (148MW) was renewed for two years.
Power Solutions Industrial – softer conditions in some markets
Organic growth was 10% implying Q4 at c.10% (Q3 +12%, Q2 +9%, Q1 +9%), we believe close to flat ex the 53rd week. EBITA was up 44% organically, with the margin at 15% (FY 14: 11%). They are seeing softer conditions in Singapore and other mining-related markets.
Rental Solutions – slow start to 2016, cautious outlook
Organic growth was flat implying Q4 flat (Q3 -1%, Q2 c.+2%, Q1 c.-1%), down high single digit ex the extra week. EBITA was down 9% organically with the margin down to 16% from 17%. They had a slow start to 2016.
Valuation
Aggreko trades on a 12-month forward P/E of 13x vs. a LR average of 17x and a cyclical low of 7x in 2002 and 2009. We do not expect material changes to consensus today.

11:19 am
PM

Assessing the $ and c of the investment slowdown
In recent notes ("Trouble down the line", "The outlook for OPEC production capacity")
we detailed the meaningful slow-down in activity we are seeing across the industry.
This is being driven by a reassessment of portfolios, on grounds of affordability and in
reaction to structural and cyclical deflationary dynamics. In this note we show the effect
of this slowdown on investment levels. The results have been dramatic.
A staggering fall in investment
Using our global coverage universe of 89 major integrated, E&P and emerging market
oil & gas companies and following the latest round of company updates, we estimate
capex will fall by 44% over 2014-16. This is a staggering $232bn of annual upstream
investment. Our coverage universe accounts for 64.8Mboe/d or 43% of global oil and
gas production, more if we were to gross up for partner participation. Low oil and gas
prices are also impacting the ostensibly robust downstream where integrated budget
cuts mean that capex is also likely to be down by 34% or $22bn.

PM

Activity or productivity?
As we highlighted in our recent note "Upstream costs: deflation accelerates" there is a
material self-help opportunity for the industry. Supply chain costs are significantly down
and companies are highlighting meaningful project scoping improvements, although in
both cases these are somewhat theoretical as there is barely any new activity being
contracted. Thus the fall in spending is largely activity driven. This is clear in industry
data such as the US rig count (down 74% from the Sept 14 peak), the international
offshore rig count (down 29% from its Nov 14 peak), and the dwindling order books of
the oilfield service industry. Projected capex intensity in the upstream industry implies a
level of efficiency (F&D) not seen in a decade - unlikely in our view.
A looming crunch
The scale of the decline in investment perhaps provides some insight into why a fall in
the oil price isn't as unequivocally positive for the global economy as had been thought.
Meanwhile work on productivity continues and the need to show that this has been
addressed likely means only a slow pick-up in spending as and when oil prices stabilise
and begin to rise. Absent demand problems this confirms a looming capacity shortage

PM

Not pretty

The thesis we go for here quite a bit is the idea that the engineering side of oil services isn't in great shape.

BE

But the consultancy side might be in better shape than expected. Because as we all know, when companies are maw-mawing about cost cutting and rationalisation, they reach for consultants.

BE

So, yes, Aggreko would seem to be in a tough spot (as there's not much consulting needed to hire a diesel generator for your shale well).

11:31 am
BE

Main surprises Whitbread's Q4 trading statement highlights some weakness at the
Costa division and to a lesser extent at Premier Inn. Premier Inn revenue growth slowed to
2.2% LFL in Q4 (4.6% SGe, 3% consensus; 4.7% Q3, 5.0% H1) despite high occupancy
rates (71.4%, + 0.3%) and 6.9% growth in the number of rooms available (vs 7.4% in Q3
and 8.1% H1). This is almost in line with the industry in the London area, with London
RevPAR declining by -3.6% (vs -3.3% for the industry), but the Region area is weaker than
the industry with RevPAR increasing by +1.5% vs industry on +3.4%. Nevertheless,
regional occupancy remained above the market at 70.6%. Revenue growth slowed again at
Costa at 0.5% LfL in Q4, lagging SGe and consensus on 3% (and vs +2.5% Q3, +4.6% Q2,
+5.0% Q1) due to lower footfall and a relatively warm winter. Whitbread reiterated plans to
open 5,500 new Premier Inn rooms and 200 Costa shops and plans to open 5,000 new
rooms and 230 new stores next year.

BE

The slowdown in Q4 at Costa and
Premier Inn may affect investor perception even if the weak stock performance (-14% over
3 months) already partly reflects this deceleration. Our target price is the rounded average
of three valuation methods: a DCF (5,330p, risk-free rate 1.7%, risk premium 5.5%, Beta
1.1), an SOP (5,365p) and a peer comparison with the hotel sector (4,955p).

BE

(@doeswalk: yep. That window's closed now. They blew it.)

11:32 am

11:33 am
BE

Caz from the conference call.

BE

 FY17 trading expectations for Premier Inn. Management expects
FY17 RevPAR to be up 2.5% for the UK market, in line with STR
forecasts, and Whitbread should trend lower once the negative impact of
room extensions is factored in. This compares to our forecasts of 3.0%.
 FY17 trading expectations for Costa. Management commented that
assuming “2-3%” like-for-like growth at Costa is “reasonable”. This
compares to our forecasts of 3.0%. Like-for-like growth of 3.2% in
FY16 has been equally weighted between pricing and transaction
volumes. While Costa has “options” for further price increases going
forward, management are not expecting to increase prices again in the
short term, and will aim to maintain a better value proposition than key
competitors Nero and Starbucks.
 FY16 Net Debt is expected to be “around £900m” This compares to
Bloomberg consensus £874m and to JPM forecasts of £912m.
 Capex guidance of £700m for FY17 compares to Bloomberg consensus
£617m and to JPMe £721m. Although a similar number to FY16, this
should be “more weighted towards Costa than it has been in history”,
with a larger number of store refurbishments and the opening of a new
roastery. Management commented that £700m will remain a “good
proxy” for normal capex spend going forward. This could be partly
financed by sales & leasebacks (£100m targeted for FY17, historically
c.£50m p.a. at yields of 5.2-5.3%).
 Margin outlook is stable across divisions. While Premier Inn RevPAR
may fall below the 3.0% rate generally assumed to be needed to fully
offset cost inflation, the stronger mix of extensions should be supportive
(hotel-level fixed costs better amortised). Costa has seen margin progress
in FY16, some of which will be reinvested in the business in FY17.
 Strategy review not before November. The complete FY results
presentation on 26th April will include more details on the rollout targets
across Premier Inn and Costa. However, management do not expect to
hold a formal investor day before November 2016.

BE

11:39 am
BE

We downgrade Imperial Brands to Neutral (from Buy) following the stock’s
solid performance and with risks now skewed to the downside on
upcoming catalysts in the UK, namely the 2016 budget and plain
packaging (we estimate Imperial’s exposure to the UK is 18% of FY16E
EBIT). Since adding Imperial to our Buy List on June 16, 2015, the stock is
up 17.5% vs. the FTSE World Europe decline of 5.1% (in GBP). Our staples
coverage was up 11.7% (GBP) on an equal weighted basis over the period.
Our estimates and 12-month price target of 3,910p are unchanged.

BE

As highlighted in our note: Plain pack deep dive, December 9, 2015, plain
packaging will come into force on May 16, 2016, and Imperial has the most
to lose from potential market share losses and consumer downtrading, in
our view; we quantified the risk at 3% of group EBIT over the next 5 years.
Australia is the only tobacco plain pack precedent (December 2012), and
the government introduced a more aggressive excise tax hike program
from December 2013. The combination of the two has led to a difficult
pricing environment for tobacco manufacturers there, and while we have
no visibility on a potential change to the UK government’s tobacco excise
plan at the upcoming 2016 UK budget (March 16 release date), we see
risks for Imperial as skewed to the downside. In this report we analyse the
potential impact from an ‘Australia-like’ excise tax plan on the UK cigarette
profit pool (-15% CAGR over the next 5 years) vs. a ‘no-change’ scenario
(+6% CAGR).
Our valuation methodology for Imperial is weighted 70% to our P/E-based
value (13.5x CY17E EPS, unchanged), with a 30% weighting to reflect an
M&A component (15.1x CY16E EV/EBITDA, unchanged). Key risks to our
view and price target include improving/worsening share trends in key
markets, better/worse-than-expected pricing and cost savings, and FX &
bond yield volatility.

PM

Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 146.60, up 11.2 (+8.27%), High: 147.15, Low: 137.00, Volume: 56.12m
11:47 am
BE

Doing the post results tour at the moment. Caz yesterday.

BE

Key points from the briefing were
(i) the $1-2bn increase in asset disposal target vs Dec’15 reflects increased
visibility on pricing indications and the size of stakes GLEN is preparing to
sell; (ii) GLEN is well funded with greater than $15bn of available liquidity and market
concerns around funding risk in H2’15 were exaggerated; (iii) management is
re-positioning the capital structure to attain a BBB+ credit rating and ~2x
ND/EBITDA by 2017. Our positive investment thesis remains intact. We see a
clear set of catalysts across 2016, plus greater than $3bn of credible FCF guided, that will
reduce balance sheet stress and drive an equity re-rating. We remain OW.

BE

$4-5bn of asset sales expected by Jun’15: The increased disposal target for
2016 of $4-5bn ($2-3bn in Dec'15) is a function of the advanced nature of
negotiations and that indications from bidders have been received. This is
most relevant in Agriculture in our view, where the CFO stated GLEN is
targeting a sale of between 30-49%, though it has received offers for 100%.
Based on our previous valuation of $8.0bn for Agriculture, a 30-49% sale
would imply potential cash proceeds of $2.4-3.9bn from this asset alone.
GLEN is open-minded to either a single or multiple partners in Agriculture.
The residual asset sales are also progressing to a H1'16 conclusion.
Infrastructure sales proceeds are expected at ~$200m, Lomas Bayas and
Cobar valuations were not speculated, with further proceeds expected from
other precious metals assets that are not core to, nor provide synergies to,
GLEN’s Marketing activities.

11:48 am
BE

Aspires to long term BBB+ credit rating: GLEN was downgraded from
BBB to BBB- in Feb’16. Whilst management believes equity and credit
investor concerns for its balance sheet risk are exaggerated, the downturn in
commodity prices since H1’15 has forced GLEN to reassess its optimum
capital structure in light of its public market status. Management now
believe leverage and capital metrics consistent with BBB+ would be
comparable to peer group Industrials that equity investors perceive to have
low credit risk. Management remain comfortable with their headroom to
sustain an investment grade credit rating. Mr Kalmin stated Marketing could
continue to operate with acceptable scale and profitability even if GLEN
was downgraded to sub-investment grade, but it would incur greater
operational complexity. GLEN retains greater than $15bn of liquidity for Marketing,
composed of long-dated, unsecured debt facilities that pushes refinancing
risk out to circa 2019.

BE

Etc.

BE

Here's what Jefferies made of its post-results visit from Cutifani.

BE

We hosted Anglo's CEO, Mark Cutifani, FD, Rene Medori, and Head of IR, Paul
Galloway, for meetings in the US yesterday. Investors are in general skeptical
about the company's ability to deliver on its planned restructuring. We are
waiting for real progress before including the potential value uplift in our
analysis. The ball is in Anglo's court, and it is time for mgmt to prove the
doubters wrong.
Core Anglo has value: Anglo's restructuring plan involves selling non core assets to
pay down debt and improve margins. According to mgmt, core Anglo (DeBeers, Platinum,
Copper) will consist of just 16 assets (versus 45 today) and will generate $2.5bn-$4.0bn of
EBITDA through the cycle with net debt of just $6bn (versus Anglo's net debt of $12.9bn). At the midpoint of the EBITDA range and a mid-cycle EV/EBITDA multiple of 6.5x, core Anglo's fair equity value would be $15.3bn, or 833p per share.

11:55 am
BE

Restructuring risks: Anglo believes that selling non-core assets is a better approach than
issuing equity or selling core assets at premium multiples. Mr Cutifani argues that the
resource optionality within tier-1 mines is difficult to value and it is unlikely that full value
would be realized in a sale. In the case of non-core assets, the difference between Anglo's
assumed valuation and the buyer's valuation should be mostly a function of differing
commodity price assumptions. Mgmt believes it can realize full value for these non-core
assets. Investors, however, are concerned that the sale process will take too much time and
that the company's ability to sell these assets for "full value" depends on commodity prices
staying firm. Several investors would prefer an equity issuance as a faster, less risky solution.
Either way, it is clear that deleveraging is essential for Anglo.
Fade the rally: Based on our analysis, the tradeoff between risk and reward is not favorable
in AAL shares at the current price. The recent rally has been extraordinary, with the AAL
share price up 137% since Jan 20. Some of that could be attributed to a modest recovery in
commodity prices and improved sentiment toward the sector, but we are reluctant to give
Anglo additional credit for restructuring targets at this time. We would take profits after the
recent strength.
Valuation/Risks
Higher commodity prices and/or successful restructuring are risks to our Underperform
rating. Our 300p target is at a discount to NPV due to operational risks. We are not modeling restructuring benefits at this time.

PM

Genel Energy (GENL LN – 82p) – Full Year Results: Today's results, despite the markdown in Taq Taq's carrying value, underlines a year of continued growth, and with the KRG's payable formula, we are confident in the host government’s drive to ensure that all parties get treated fairly. The progress made on the gas monetisation initiative also provides support in the medium to longer term, but there are issues that continue to provide headwinds. While there is the incumbent geopolitical risk associated with the region, of more concern to us is the fact that for a company of this size, to have a single revenue generating region is a significant risk, which is heightened by the fact that there is so much volatility in the region. Consequently, and until such times as this is remedied, we believe that the Company will trade at a lower NAV multiple than its peers. That said, it's current multiple is not a fair reflection of the value of the business currently.

BE

Have some RBC too.

BE

Having announced on Monday a halving of reserves in the high-profile Taq Taq field and $1bn impairment charge, today's FY15 earnings release included no
surprises. We expect management to receive additional 'heat' for the downgrade at this morning's presentation, but they will probably look to utilise the event to
highlight the company's potential - a low cost operation, gas development opportunities, cash on the balance sheet and no near-term debt repayments. Given
the recent news and 2015's board changes, we expect significant demand on management's time through H1/16.
Financials largely pre-announced: Ahead of today Genel announced it produced 84,900b/d in FY15 and generated revenues of $344m. Gross profit was
$136m and following an exploration write-off of $173m and the Taq Taq impairment charge of $1.04bn (both previously announced), the operating loss of $1.16bn
was in line with our forecast. Capex in 2015 was $250m, slightly lower than our ~$280m forecast and Genel ended the year with cash in hand of $455m and
bonds of $730m. Genel’s KRI capex guidance for 2016 is unchanged at $80-120m.
Spending: Genel intends to run its business in Kurdistan on a broadly cash neutral basis. Spending in FY16 is budgeted at $20m/month, which should fall
short of the company's monthly cash revenues. The exploitation of the Miran and Bina Bawi gas fields (GENL 100%) are a source of significant growth potential,
however, 2016 spending looks set to be limited to just $25m.
Balance sheet: The cash and bond enjoy a high-profile, but the company has a ~$425m receivable in Kurdistan, this is largely non-current, but the new
payment mechanism in Kurdistan should help accelerate the recovery of this cash via the IRR-linked PSC. However, Genel also has contingency payments of
up to $145m to pay for the Bina Bawi acquisition and a $30m+ drilling commitment offshore Morocco.
Newsflow: We expect DNO, the field operator, to publish a year-end reserves report for the Tawke field in the w/c 14th March. Both Genel and DNO appear
keen to drill the Peshkabir-2 appraisal/exploration well this year. Genel will be speaking on the 9th March in London in our Winter Lunch series.

12:01 pm
BE

Carillion this morning reported its FY 15 results, with total revenue up
+13%, as expected, at £4.6bn, driven by 10% organic growth. Profit before
tax increased 2% to £176.5m, 1% ahead of our estimates. Group margins
were 5.1%, below our expectations of 5.8% and FY 14 at 6.2%. This was
primarily due to margin declines in the Construction Services division.
The group’s EPS was 35.0p, a 1% increase on FY 14 at 33.7p. The
company announced a 3% increase in its full year dividend, 4% above our
expectations at 18.25p (FY 14 17.75p). We retain our Overweight rating,
and expect Bloomberg consensus for FY 16 to rise approximately 1%.
 Support Services. Revenue was up 9% at £2,534.2m, driven by organic
growth and the acquisitions of Rokstad Corporation and the Outland
Group in Canada. Margins were maintained at 5.8% (FY 14 5.8%),
despite higher than normal mobilization costs. The value of new orders
and probable orders won in FY 15 was £1.2bn (FY 14 £2.9bn) primarily
due to the UK General Election.
 PPP Projects. Revenue was up +19% at £192.8m and above our forecast
of £162.5m, due to construction progress on new projects won in FY 14
and FY 15.
 Middle East Construction Services. Revenue was up 20% at £601.6m,
due to progress on new and existing contracts. This expansion was
partially offset by a reduction in operating margins at 4.2% (FY 5.0%),
due to an increasingly competitive landscape. The company expects
lower margins in FY 16, but to mitigate this and the potential effect of
low oil prices by targeting projects in the UK Export Finance and PPP
projects. The total value of orders and probable orders is £0.8bn (FY 14
£0.9bn).
 Construction Services (ex. ME). The company delivered strong revenue
growth, +16% at £1,258.3m, driven by the UK, which increased to
£1.1bn (FY 14 £0.9bn). This more than offset the planned reduction in
construction revenue in Canada. Operating margins were down y/y at 3%
(FY 14 3.8%), and in line with expectations.
 Balance sheet. Average net debt levels rose to £538m in FY15 from
£490m in FY 14, representing 2.2x ND/EBITDA.
 Outlook. The company has stated that despite challenging trading
conditions in several of their markets, it continues to see improvements,
especially in the UK.

The FY15 results were slightly soft, but of most interest to us was the outlook statement for 2016 (below). While the macro is undeniably volatile and subdued at present, which will weigh on ‘Commercial’ end markets (38% of revs), we were hoping that the forward commentary would be more constructive in defence and security given where we are in the ‘cycle’. Commentary around the focus on the cost base is encouraging given the top line isn’t doing what it’s meant to be doing, but we’re keen to understand why the growth in defence and security isn’t coming through at this point in the ‘cycle’ and at what point we can expect to see a recovery ....

BE

Highlights

· Revenues £2,072m (vs £1,852m in FY14) +12% yoy (due to Aeroflex) but -1% organic with good non-US defence/security growth (+4%) offset by commercial headwinds (-6%). 4% miss vs. BBG cons.

· Underlying trading profit £332m (£287m) – another 4% miss, benefitted yoy from non-repeat of £15m provision.

· Margin 16.0% (15.5%) however 2014 included an £15m or 80bps aerial refueling provision that didn’t repeat

· EPS 19.5p (18.5p) +9% yoy, but -4% miss vs. BBG cons.

· DPS 11.18p (10.65p) – 4.3% yield.

· Free cash flow: £106m (£114m) – higher capex +50% yoy is the main driver of weakness.

· Net debt: £1,207m (£1,223m) – 2.9x EBITDA

· Communications & Connectivity weak -4% organic on lower Marine SATCOM (poor shipping/oil and gas markets) and wireless revenues in commercial land after a strong 2014.

· Advanced Electronics Systems strong +10% organic off C-130 production and KC-46 development and refueling revenues.

· Mission Systems weak -7% organic on weak US defence/security volumes on mature programmes.

· Aviation Services flat +1% organic.

· Valuation 12.4x FY17E PE, 13.7x FY17E EV/EBIT

2016 outlook

· “defence and security portfolio will be stable” – 62% of 2015 revenue

· “commercial markets remain subdued” – 38% of 2015 revenue

· “Cobham will continue to manage its cost base proactively together with an increased focus on cash generation and debt reduction.”

· “H2 to bias to earnings”

· BBG cons FY16E revs of £2,104m was looking for a c.-2.5% decline but on FY15A is +1.5% of growth.

Here's some Michael Blogg from Investec

PM

Investor focus is firmly on Melrose’s next acquisition. Management seem increasingly confident that they will be able to execute upon an acquisition at the right price given more favourable valuation multiples. Timing is difficult to determine but a confluence of factors raises the potential in our view. In the meantime, Brush is trading as expected in depressed markets and we make no change to our trading estimates. Our new PT of 360p (was 325p) reflects a better cash and pension deficit outturn. Hold on for the next acquisition.

PM

Brush delivered revenue of £261.1m (down 17% y-o-y) and operating profit of £38.5m (-38%, margin of 14.7%) compared to our £260.0m and £39.5m. We maintain our FY16E operating profit forecast (£41.5m) which will benefit from FX, restructuring undertaken in FY14/15 (completed) and new overhead reduction measures. The near term outlook remains challenging. Within Brush, the aftermarket delivered a strong end to FY15 after a slow H1. Order intake in FY15 was down 6%.
Dividend: The group has declared a final dividend of 2.6p (5.3p in FY14), which reflects the group’s current size and profit/cash generating capacity. We assume a full year dividend of 4.2p in FY16E.
Balance sheet: On a proforma basis, post the cash return and a pension top-up of £8.8m, the company had net cash of £54m. The cash position is better than we had expected. At the FY16E year-end we now assume net cash of £58m (vs £37m previously). The pro-forma pension deficit has been reduced to £8.4m. The remaining pension assets and liabilities will be disposed of with Brush.
Our view: The track record is unparalleled and we believe shareholders should be fully supportive of the next acquisition. In 2016 Melrose is aiming to offer access to a sizeable turnaround story at an attractive price and at a low point (probably) in the broader economic cycle. If history is to be repeated then this should negate the immediate requirement for top-line growth (a rarity), bringing instead a focus on driving operational improvement and better cash generation, to a degree not available elsewhere in the sector. We recommend retaining the option to participate, and reiterate our Buy.
